title: Relative velocity | Demonstration of constant speed with a moving trampoline

last_post.content:
A nice empirical demonstration of Galileo's principle of relativity: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIMNS0YiHzY

If one replaces the person on the trampoline with a light beam bouncing up and down between two horizontal mirrors, and assumes that the speed of light is \(c\) in every inertial frame, one obtains (from Pythagoras) the well-known 'light clock" thought experiment of Einstein that derives the fact that such clocks slow down by a factor of √(1−𝑣²/𝑐²) when moving at a velocity \(v\).

title: How In-Ear Monitors are Making Better Musicians

last_post.content:
Why do orchestras need conductors?

There are various reasons, of course, but here at 0:26 Adam Neely suggests one I hadn't thought about:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mHoljbkyAEs

The speed of light is faster than the speed of sound!

For a large orchestra it can take 0.1 seconds for sound to make a round trip between two performers... and that's a huge amount of time in music. So, get them synched up using light signals instead!

title: A. Vivaldi: Concerti con molti strumenti [Europa Galante - F. Biondi]

last_post.content:
How would the world be different if Bach's Brandenburg Concerti were lost... or had become popular much earlier?

They were not an unprecedented bolt out of blue. Compare the Concerti con molti strumenti, by Vivaldi:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZgE_x1-kkqY

Similar in some ways! And probably no coincidence: Bach spent time transcribing the works of Vivaldi.

So if the Brandenburg Concerti were lost, maybe we'd spend more time listening to Vivaldi!

(4/n, n = 4)

title: J.S. Bach Brandenburg Concertos  1 - 6, Claudio Abbado

last_post.content:
Listening to the Brandenburg Concerti again, I realized they're a great example of the importance of luck.

Bach dedicated them to Christian Ludwig, Margrave of Brandenburg-Schwedt, hoping to get a job. But Ludwig didn't have enough musicians to play them. Bach didn't get the job. The score was left unused in the Margrave's library until his death.

title: We need to talk about Dropout

last_post.content:
New video premieres in 15 minutes: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zu0hyIwKDmE

"We need to talk about Dropout", in which we talk about media, pivoting to video, the life and death of CollegeHumor, and discuss the Dropout video player.

As promised, on this last day of the year, I am writing the summary of the year 2022 and what it meant for GRASP.

First off, #GRASP is a #Lisp (s-expression) editor designed with mobile devices/tactile interfaces in mind. Here's what using it on a mobile device is supposed to look&feel like:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H0YNZCO7gyQ

The above is a video recoreded with the old prototype (the one that I have presented during 2021 Scheme Workshop).

However, with the beginning of the year 2022, after some experimentation, I decided to rewrite the whole program from scratch.

The reasons for that were the following:
- the old prototype was written in Java (becasue, when I started, it was the only option I knew about for writing Android apps on an Android device), so that I would not be able to use GRASP to edit its own source code

- after I integrated GRASP with Kawa Scheme, I learned enough about Java, Android and Kawa to attempt rewriting the editor in Kawa Scheme

- after integration with Kawa Scheme the build times of the APK file increased significantly, so I needed a way for testing pieces of the application without rebuilding the whole thing

- the representation chosen in that prototype was fairly ad-hoc, and it would be difficult to modify it to represent dotted lists

- I wanted to be able to work on (and in) the app not only on my phone, but also on a conventional computer with a keyboard and a mouse

- I felt that adding certain features (like undo or keyboard editing) was hard in the existing code base

- I'm neither experienced nor passionate about Java (actually GRASP was my first and last program written in Java), whereas I am both passionate and experienced when it comes to writing Scheme

The point regading being able to test the application without rebuilding it, and about being able to write both on the mobile and conventional computers, has lead me to some interesting by-products.

First - for the purpose of testing - I created a backend which spits out GRASP rendering as ASCII art, which lets me write unit tests in the following way:

https://github.com/panicz/grasp-android/blob/master/stages/retreat/GRASP/src/test-painter.scm#L252

Second - I also built a terminal version of GRASP, so that I have a piece of code that I can quite literally run both on a computer and on the phone (via Termux,
which is my development environment). Dragging expressions in a terminal using a mouse feels insane!

Some interesting stuff I apparently didn't notice the first time in updates to AT&T's terms of service, which you agreed to by continuing to use AT&T. This language is designed to insulate AT&T from liability in the event someone SIM swaps your phone number and uses that to steal your identity, crypto, etc. There's quite a bit of ongoing litigation about this very subject.

https://www.att.com/legal/terms.consumerServiceAgreement.html

"AT&T is not responsible for losses incurred as a result of your or a third-party’s use of your AT&T wireless number or other AT&T Service as a source of authentication or verification in connection with any social media, email, financial, cryptocurrency or other account;"

....."To the greatest extent permitted by law, AT&T is not liable to you for any damages of any kind resulting in any way from:

the installation, maintenance, removal, or technical support of AT&T Services, even if the damage results from the ordinary negligence of our installer or other representative;
any unauthorized access to your AT&T Accounts or AT&T Services (including the use of your AT&T Accounts or AT&T Services to access a third-party account), even if the unauthorized access was the result of ordinary negligence by an AT&T employee, representative, agent, or any person or entity purporting to act on AT&T’s behalf;"

Whew, that's some heavy stuff. Meanwhile, please enjoy this latest SIM-swap rap. h/t @nixonnixoff

title: Preliminaries in automated red teaming in hardening digital identity management systems

last_post.content: Next was a short talk by Anh Tuan Le on automating #RedTeaming approaches for #identity management system #security at #AlanTuringInstitute. There's a focused on decentralized systems here, which as people in the Q&A pointed out might be infeasible for localities with unreliable internet access, still worth a listen if you're in the space https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wuMCbKptwyQ (5/11)

Next was a nice talk by Azalia Mirhoseini on using #MachineLearning to design computational systems for machine learning! Accelerator-based approaches seem critical for current #ML trends to continue, and it seems likely that methods like this will be essential as complexity and compute costs continue to increase https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jr3FudQpNs0 (4/11)

title: Web3: The Future of Platforms and Business Ecosystems (Scott Kominers)

last_post.content: Next was an interesting talk on the potential of #Web3 to weaken #platform power by @skominers at #StanfordCodeX's Computational #Antitrust Conference. Other work has made me somewhat skeptical of this claim, but it's still intriguing to think about these possibilities https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6qWXV2sYH-U (3/11)

First up was a fantastic talk by Cynthia Dwork on using a theoretical #stats framework to prove #algorithmic #fairness bounds at #AlanTuringInstitute. There are some practical takeaways, but some claims should be taken with a grain of salt as they heavily rely on unrealistic statistical properties and take a techno-solutionist approach to fairness that I think is only one piece of the puzzle https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5jALzHR_50w&t=2s (2/11) #AI #ethics #AIEthics

Stories from the Salish Sea: The Kelp Highway

My good friend Chris Morgan narrated a project for Seattle Aquarium focused on the ecology environments around us here in Puget Sound. I can't recommend this series highly enough. The cinematography (and subject matter) are absolutely amazing.

A great place to start is here: https://youtu.be/jg1M4ZdDiY8

The entire series is here: https://salishsea.seattleaquarium.org

Worth a boost if you love the kelp that sustains our marine environments.

title: Pre- KEIO TECHNO-MALL 2022（第2回）「慶應義塾が進める医療ヘルスケア領域のデータベース構築とそれを用いたオープンイノベーションによる事業創出の取り組み」

last_post.content:
興味深い慶応大のヘルスケアイノベーションイベントを見て、参考になりました。

最初に中村先生は明確に日本の高齢者ケア状態を客観的なデータと主観的なデータを組み合わせることによって検討して総合的なヘルスコモンズネットワークモデルを提案しました。このモデルはAIとアルゴリズムを用いて複数なヘルスケア機関と連携してお年寄りの方のために効果的でカスタマイズされたソリューションを提供できるようにできます。心配しているのはデータバイアスなどの課題はあげませんでした。

最後に陣崎先生は「AIホスピタル」のコンセプトについて発表しました。このトークにもいろんな大事なアイデアが説明されて、人材資源が不足している日本でデータを用いて効果的な病院機関が作れるのは必要だと思います。しかしAI倫理はこの活動に大きな影響を与える可能性は高いですので、倫理が最初から研究に盛り込んだ方がいいと思います。

このような研究は日本で行っているのは素晴らしいと思います。このプロジェクトは世界のモデルになれるかもしれませんので、AI倫理が中心的にするべきだと思います

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EuTT7rS_JGU #AI

Next was an informative talk by @PawelAdrjan on global #RemoteWork trends from #Indeed #data at the Digital Futures at #Work Research Centre (Digit). With some thorough caveats at the beginning, this talk nicely reviews where the data appears to show workplace strategy trends settling. Useful for level setting and for #governments, but for organizations this shouldn't influence strategy b/c companies have absolutely no idea what they're doing on #workplace strategy https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQwmszM8B5U (8/9)

Next was an introduction to #AlanTuringInstitute's #data #justice initiative. This is a good quick summary of the potential harms of #algorithms and data-driven technologies https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HPs1u5aibHM (7/9)

Next was two panel discussions at the #TechPolicyLab's We Robot conference, covering #AI #ethics and #regulation. The panels themselves were great, but a lot of the Q&A was... something https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CeWMlzcc2KE (6/9)

Next was an interesting talk by Steve Tadelis on running an extremely effective ad experiment to increase COVID-19 #vaccination rates at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. The effect size here is bonkers, and for the life of me I can't find alternative explanations for how a relatively simple intervention generated such a huge effect. Kudos to the authors! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-0jas3d9Cpg (5/9)

Report back from Twitter filter fuzzing.

What Twitter is blocking

Twitter is filtering links to known Mastodon instances, but still allows direct links to joinmastodon.org. The filtering seems to happen whenever Twitter's WYSIWYG editor recognizes a valid domain name and that domain happens to be a known Mastodon instance.
Twitter also allows linking to shortened URLs of mastodon profiles, but only once. Posting the shortened URL a second time doesn't work, implying there's some backend queue service that's checking the Location header of links and flagging the ones redirecting to Mastodon instances.

How to evade the filters

Email address spam evasion techniques work. Replacing '.' with ' . ' or [.] or [dot] all work.
URI encoding the hostname. Replace at least one of the characters in the hostname with it's URI encoded version (ex: . -> %2E, https://infosec.exchange -> https://infosec%2Eexchange). Browsers are smart enough to URI decode anything you copy/paste into the address bar.
data: URIs. Twitter does not seem to check base64 encoded data: URIs. It is possible to create a data:text/html;base64,... base64 encoded HTML URI which can be copied into the address bar and will render as HTML. While Twitter will not render data: URIs (for obvious reasons), you can still copy/paste them (at your own risk, of course).
Base64. This seems silly, but we could communicate freely on Twitter by simply Base64 encoding our tweets. This could be accomplished via some Chrome extension.

Twitter's anti-Mastodon filtering is clown shoes amateur hour.🤡​

Edit: as many have pointed out, adding a Mastodon link to the alt-text of your background image presumably still works, encoding the link as a QR code works, setting your Location or Display Name to your mastodon handle works. I only tested links to Mastodon instances in tweets.
Edit 2: someone setup a link shortening service that explicitly blocks Twitter from checking the links which seems to be working: https://spacekaren.sucks/
Edit 3: Twitter has now formalized it's Mastodon censorship policy: https://help.twitter.com/en/rules-and-policies/social-platforms-policy
Edit 4: now that I'm trending on HN, I should link to this other researcher on YouTube who did a much more in-depth analysis of Twitter's JavaScript and API requests: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oHg5SJYRHA0&t=1s
